pros: Good support systems and world renowned place to work
Happiest job I've had. Rewarding organiation that truly tries to make a difference.
Feel looked after and they take your mental health seriously. Great atmosphere to work in.
cons: Not much progression within the mental health team.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Liverpool, England
pros: Busy unit with of opportunities to apply advanced skills. Robust introduction to the unit
cons: Can be cliquey but with 180+ staff that’s to be expected. There are some very strong personalities too.
Hard to go up the ladder

pros:
Great patient care.
Renal and respiratory consultant great to work with.
cons: Moving to a new trust has opened my eyes to just how unfriendly and unprofessional the staff at Alder Hey are. Lots of in-fighting and colitis. Wards make life difficult for one another. Nurses are treated as “numbers” not human beings. Management will not support you personally or professionally. Majority of surgeons speak to nurses like dirt. When it comes to moving role or gaining a promotion it’s not what you know it’s who you know. Felt very unsafe at times when faced with aggressive parents and no support. Band 7’s not approachable.

review_title: Alder Hey Hospital NHS Foundation Trust
pros:
Quality of health care provided at Alder Hey to children
Equality & Diversity
Sense of humour of staff
cons:
Doesn't feel like it's working as a cohesive whole.
Back-biting, politics and in-fighting.
Staff taken for granted, asked to do more and more work with no extra money.
Lack of communication.
Bosses know where to find you when they want something doing, other than that, you can forget it.

pros: Good opportunity to learn new skills, new building, friendly atmosphere, up to date policies and guidelines on meditech, leading ultimately to significant gains for the future of the NHS.
cons: More lockers would be beneficial for staff in the critical care unit as there are lots of staff working in the unit.

pros: On the outside looking in its a great hospital, new build, new wards and new systems
cons: Management get invested alder hey paying for degrees and masters but front line staff get told there's no money.  Nrw management appear with no job being advertised but nursing and clinical posts going through scrutiny and then rejected. There is A LOT of bullying and its really clicky I'm in my 40s and never seen anything like it in my life. HR turn a blind eye while the staff counselling service's are stretched and union reps going off sick

job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Liverpool, England
pros: Excellent manager and delight to work for
cons: None at all, perfect working environment

job_title: Accountant in Kingston upon Hull, East Riding of Yorkshire, Yorkshire and the Humber, England
pros: good work life balance and great pension
